Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Reconstructing Airflow in the Nasal Cavity of Mammals
Award.AbstractNarration:
The mammalian nose houses a complex set of paper-thin bones known as turbinals. Turbinals are involved in both the sense of smell and conditioning inspired air, and yet their function is not well understood. This is true despite the fact that a better knowledge of nasal anatomy and function is essential for progress in predicting particulate deposition in human airways, improving intranasal drug delivery, and the development of artificial sniffers for the detection of dangerous substances such as explosives. Some of the most important questions about turbinal function concern aspects of airflow through the nose. How do they direct air to the olfactory region? Are there separate pathways for respiration and olfaction? What can differences among species in the architecture of the turbinals tell us about the efficiency of odorant reception and heat and water conservation? To answer these questions, this project brings together scientists from two disparate fields, biology and engineering, to advance our understanding of respiration and olfaction. By combining modern high-resolution medical imaging, state-of-the-art models of flow, and data on nasal soft tissue distribution, this cross-disciplinary collaboration will be the first to apply novel computational modeling tools (e.g., 3-D anatomical reconstruction, computational fluid dynamics [CFD]) and experimental measurement techniques (e.g., use of anatomically-correct transparent physical models) to develop new form-function relationships for the nose. To do so, the 3-D nasal anatomy of five mammal species will be reconstructed from magnetic resonance images (MRI) of intact heads, computed tomography (CT) scans of their bony turbinals, and laboratory analysis of the distribution of olfactory vs. respiratory tissue. To enable future studies, paired sets of MRI scans of intact heads and CT scans of the cleaned skulls will be used to develop a method that corrects CT-derived image data of dry skull specimens for the absence of nasal mucosa. This will permit the study of nasal airflow using existing museum collections of skulls alone rather than intact heads, thereby greatly expanding the range of species and function that can be studied. Finally, to increase knowledge of nasal function beyond the two relatively short-snouted groups that have received the most attention, viz., primates and carnivores, the turbinals of 10-15 ungulate species will be reconstructed from CT scans of dry skulls and analyzed for turbinal dimensions.
Over 10,000 CT slices of the skulls of 11-16 species of mammals, as well as paired sets of MRI scans of intact heads and CT scans of skulls for three individual mammals will be generated. All new scans will be deposited in the NSF Digital Morphology Library at the University of Texas, Austin (www.digimorph.org) for public access within 5 years of receiving funding for this project. Similarly, all of the numerical CFD models developed during this study will be made available via a website to be established by the PIs and hosted by Penn State University. Numerous graduate students and undergraduates will be trained in aspects of both biology and engineering as part of this project. Minority graduate and undergraduate students will be recruited through dedicated programs at each institution, and the investigators will continue their ongoing outreach efforts to high school students and lay audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT OUTCOMES

     The mammalian nose houses a complex set of paper-thin bones known as turbinals (Fig. 1). When air is inhaled during breathing or sniffing, the air passes over and around the turbinal bones, all of which are covered in moist tissue.  Consequently, turbinals are involved in both the sense of smell and warming and moistening inspired air, and yet their function is not well understood. This is true despite the fact that a better knowledge of nasal anatomy and function is essential for 1) progress in predicting particulate deposition in human airways, 2) improving intranasal drug delivery, and 3) the development of artificial sniffers for the detection of dangerous substances such as explosives. Some of the most important questions about turbinal function concern aspects of airflow through the nose. How do these complicated bones direct air to the olfactory region?  Are there separate pathways for respiration and olfaction? What can differences among species in the architecture and size of the turbinal bones tell us about the efficiency of odorant reception and heat and water conservation? To answer these questions, we brought together scientists from two disparate fields, biology and engineering, to advance our understanding of respiration and olfaction. Using modern high-resolution medical imaging, state-of-the-art models of flow, and data on nasal soft tissue distribution, this cross-disciplinary study is the first to apply novel computational modeling tools (e.g., 3-D anatomical reconstruction, and computational fluid dynamics [CFD]) to document form-function relationships for the mammal nose. The nasal anatomy of three species, bobcat (Lynx rufus), coyote (Canis latrans), and white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus) was reconstructed from magnetic resonance images (MRI) of intact heads and laboratory analysis of the distribution of olfactory vs. respiratory tissue (Fig. 2). Remarkably, despite marked differences in snout length and architecture of the turbinal bones, the flow pathways for breathing and smelling were similarly separated in all three species. In all cases, the olfactory pathway ran along the upper or dorsal surface of the nasal cavity and was directed to the region with the greatest density of smell receptors (Fig. 2).  By contrast, the respiratory flow bypassed this region, flowing more ventrally in the nasal cavity to the pharynx and trachea. Flow models revealed that delivery of odorant-laden air to the posterior olfactory sensory region was enhanced greatly by active sniffing, thus providing a functional explanation for this widespread behavior.

The computational flow model analyses were limited to three species because 3-D CFD model building is both time and labor intensive. To broaden our study, we used high-resolution CT scans of museum skulls of over 50 species of mammals to quantify the surface area of three structures within the nose, the olfactory turbinals, respiratory turbinals, and the cribriform plate (CP). The CP is a bony plate that separates the nasal cavity from the olfactory bulbs of the brain (Fig. 3). The CP is perforated with holes through which pass the nerves that carry information to the brain from the olfactory receptors spread across the olfactory turbinals. Our results indicate that the size of the respiratory turbinals is determined largely by body mass, whereas the surface area of the olfactory turbinals is larger in species with a greater reliance on their sense of smell.  For example, dog-like carnivores, such as gray wolves and foxes, have relatively larger olfactory surface areas than cat-like carnivores such as bobcats and mountain lions.  In addition, the size of the CP is correlated with the total surface area of the olfactory turbinals, and therefore olfactory ability (Fig. 4).  Because CP surface area is much easier to measure than olfactory turbinal surface area, it opens the door for a much wider taxonomic survey of putative olfactory ability in mammals.

In terms of downstream impacts, our study has produced over 10,000 CT slices of the skulls of 50 species of mammals, as well as three sets of MRI scans of intact heads. All of the CT scans are available in the NSF Digital Morphology Library at the University of Texas, Austin (www.digimorph.org) for public access and many of them been accessed already by other researchers. At UCLA, four graduate students (two women) and 13 undergraduates were trained in aspects of both biology and engineering as part of this project.  Three completed Ph.D. dissertations were based on data retrieved by this grant.  Of the 17 students who participated in the work, eight were women, one was Latino, and one was LGBT. Among the undergraduates, five have gone on to graduate or professional school in biology.
